dt.t: The {wi}mystery{/wi} of his disappearance has never been solved.

dt: {bc}a piece of fiction dealing usually with the solution of a {a_link|mysterious} crime
{bc}the secret or specialized practices or ritual peculiar to an occupation or a body of people
{bc}profound, inexplicable, or secretive quality or character
{bc}a religious truth that one can know only by revelation and cannot fully understand
{bc}any of the 20 events (such as the Nativity, the Crucifixion, or the Assumption) serving as a subject for meditation during the saying of the rosary
{bc}a secret religious rite believed (as in Eleusinian and Mithraic cults) to impart enduring bliss to the initiate

pt: {sc}mystery{/sc} {sc}problem{/sc} {sc}enigma{/sc} {sc}riddle{/sc} {sc}puzzle{/sc} mean something which baffles or perplexes. {sc}mystery{/sc} applies to what cannot be fully understood by reason or less strictly to whatever resists or defies explanation.
{sc}problem{/sc} applies to a question or difficulty calling for a solution or causing concern.
{sc}enigma{/sc} applies to utterance or behavior that is very difficult to interpret.
{sc}riddle{/sc} suggests an enigma or problem involving paradox or apparent contradiction.

pt.t: the {it}riddle{/it} of the reclusive pop star

pt: {sc}puzzle{/sc} applies to an enigma or problem that challenges ingenuity for its solution.

pt.t: the thief's motives were a {it}puzzle{/it} for the police

et: Middle English {it}mysterie{/it} "hidden religious truth, rite or event with religious significance, hidden meaning," borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French {it}misterie,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}mystērium{/it} "hidden religious truth revealed by God, religious rite, Eucharist," going back to Latin (in plural {it}mystēria{/it}), "secret religious rites, things not to be divulged," borrowed from Greek {it}mystḗrion,{/it} plural {it}mystḗria{/it} "religious rite to which only initiates may be admitted, secret" (in the New Testament, "religious truth revealed by God"), from {it}mys-,{/it} base of {it}mýstēs{/it} "person initiated (into a religious cult)" + {it}-tērion,{/it} suffix in words denoting instruments, place and ceremonies (derivative of {it}-tēr,{/it} agent suffix) {ma}{mat|mystic:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: something not understood or beyond understanding : enigma
a piece of fiction dealing usually with the solution of a mysterious crime
the secret or specialized practices or ritual peculiar to an occupation or a body of people

dt: {bc}a body of persons engaged in a particular trade, business, or profession {bc}{sx|guild||}

et: Middle English {it}mysterie{/it} "ministry, office, craft," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}misterium{/it} "duty, office, occupation, trade," in part Latinization of Anglo-French {it}mester, mister{/it} (continental Old French {it}mestier{/it}) "function, duty, pursuit, trade, craft, guild" (going back to Late Latin {it}mīsterium,{/it} variant of Latin {it}ministerium{/it} "office of a servant or attendant, duty, support"), in part borrowed directly from Late Latin {ma}{mat|ministry|}{/ma}

Medieval and Late Latin {it}misterium{/it} are conventionally explained as a conflation of {it}ministerium{/it} and Late Latin {it}mystērium{/it} "hidden religious truth, religious rite, Eucharist" (see {et_link|mystery:1|mystery:1}), though a Late Latin form {it}mīsterium{/it} (assuming manuscript spellings are early) would be a natural outcome of {it}ministerium{/it} with loss of the pre-tonic vowel and nasal consonant.
shortdef: a body of persons engaged in a particular trade, business, or profession : guild
